facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 611 of 1964 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 611 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated September 10, 1962 of Andhra Pradesh High Court in R.P. No. 1128 of 1959.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated September 10, 1962 of the Andhra Pradesh High Court in R.P. No. 1128 of 1959.

facts.text: Ramalingayya died in the year 1941 possessed of considerable properties including the lands.

anchor.surface_text: One Ramalingayya died in the year 1941 possessed of companysiderable properties including the lands which formed the subject matter of the above mentioned civil

facts.text: Ramalingayya adopted Chimmapudi Subrahmanyam before his death.

anchor.surface_text: revision petitions. Before his death, he had adopted the petitioner before the High Court one Chimmapudi Subrahmanyam, the respondent before this Court.

facts.text: Subrahmanyam came into possession of the properties after Ramalingayya's death.

anchor.surface_text: He came into possession of the properties of his adoptive father after the latters death.

facts.text: Ramalingayya's widow disputed the factum and validity of the adoption and claimed properties as heir.

anchor.surface_text: Ramalingayyas widow however raised a dispute about the factum and validity of the adoption and claimed the properties as the heir of her husband.

facts.text: Subrahmanyam filed suit in District Munsif, Khammam for declaration that he was adopted son.

anchor.surface_text: Subrahmanyam filed a suit in the companyrt of the District Munsif, Khammam for a declaration that he was the adopted son of Ramalingayya.

facts.text: Pending suit, widow Kaveramma had her name registered as pattadar under Hyderabad Land Revenue Act of 1317 F, s.59.

anchor.surface_text: Pending the disposal of the suit, however, Ramalingayyas widow, who was the 4th respondent in C.R.P. No.36 of 1952 before the High Court claimed, to have her

facts.text: Land revenue authorities registered widow Kaveramma as pattadar and dispossessed adopted son, putting her in possession.

anchor.surface_text: name registered in the register maintained under the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act of 1317 F. by virtue of the provisions of s. 59 of that Act. The land revenue

facts.text: Adopted son amended plaint to include prayer for possession.

anchor.surface_text: The adopted son amended his plaint by including a prayer for possession.

facts.text: In 1944, widow Kaveramma prohibited by injunction from dealing with lands.

anchor.surface_text: During the pendency of the suit, the widow Kaveramma was prohibited by an order of injunction from dealing with the lands in any way. This was sometime in the

facts.text: Trial court decreed suit of adopted son on March 24, 1951 for declaration and possession.

anchor.surface_text: The suit of the adopted son was decreed, by the trial, companyrt on March 24, 1951 both with regard to the declaration of the right of adoption and succession

facts.text: In 1952, Kaveramma leased lands to appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter, some time in the year 1952  the exact date does number appear from the records before us  Kaveramma leased the lands which were tile subject

facts.text: Widow's appeal from decree dismissed by High Court in 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Kaveramma preferred an appeal from the decree passed against her and this was dismissed by the High Court in 1954.

facts.text: Adopted son got delivery of possession through court in August 1954.

anchor.surface_text: The adopted son put the decree in execution and got delivery of posses- sion through the companyrt in August 1954.

facts.text: In September 1954, appellants surrendered possession to adopted son and executed deed.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that very soon thereafter, in September 1954 the appellants surrendered possession of the lands to him and executed a deed in respect thereof.

facts.text: On October 7, 1955, appellants filed petition for possession under S.32 Hyderabad Tenancy Act 1950, claiming 6 years possession as tenants.

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding that, about a year afterwards, they filed a petition on October 7, 1955 for possession of the lands alleging that they had been in possession

facts.text: Tahsildar ordered in favour of appellants in July 1958.

anchor.surface_text: The Tahsildar made an order in favour of the appellants in July 1958 which was upheld in appeal to the Collector in March, 1959.

facts.text: Collector upheld Tahsildar's order in March 1959.

anchor.surface_text: which was upheld in appeal to the Collector in March, 1959. This led to the revision applications before the Andhra Pradesh High Court.

facts.text: Andhra Pradesh High Court allowed Civil Revision Petitions.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court allowed the Civil Revision Petitions and this has led to the appeal.

facts.text: Appellants claimed to be tenants lawfully cultivating under s.5 of Hyderabad Tenancy Act.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued however both before the High Court and before this Court that the appellants were entitled to the benefit of s. 5, as they were lawfully cultivating

facts.text: Court found widow's possession after decree was that of trespasser, could not create rights.

anchor.surface_text: After the passing of the decree, the possession of the widow companyld only be that of a trespasser and it was number open to her to create any right in the land

facts.text: Appellants never tenants of Ramalingayya, induced by widow after decree.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before this Court never were the tenants of Ramalingayya. They were induced on the land by his widow after the decree of the suit for declaration

facts.text: District Collector judgment dated March 19, 1959 confirms lease in 1952.

anchor.surface_text: This is borne out by the judgment of, the District Collector, Khammam dated March 19, 1959 and the petition for special leave to this Court dated October 18,

facts.text: Petition for special leave dated October 18, 1962.

issues.text: Whether the appellants are entitled to possession under section 32(1) of the Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1950 as tenants?

anchor.surface_text: Notwithstanding that, about a year afterwards, they filed a petition on October 7, 1955 for possession of the lands alleging that they had been in possession for the last six years in the 71 4 capacity of tenants. Their allegation further was that the adopted son and his mother had dispossessed them from the suit lands and they therefore prayed for being put back into possession. This claim was preferred under S. 32 1  of the Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1950.

issues.text: Whether the appellants were entitled to the benefit of s.5 of the Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1950 as they were lawfully cultivating the land and should therefore be deemed to be tenants?

anchor.surface_text: It was argued however both before the High Court and before this Court that the appellants were entitled to the benefit of s. 5, as they were lawfully cultivating the land and should therefore be deemed to be tenants of such land. It was contended that the word lawfully was to be taken in conjunction with the words cultivating and the legislature intended to protect the actual tillers of the soil even if the person who, 7 1 5 put them in possession was found not to have any title to the land.

issues.text: Whether the widow, whose possession after the decree was that of a trespasser, could create any right in the land in favour of the appellants thereby making their cultivation lawful under s.5?

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before this Court never were the tenants of Ramalingayya. They were induced on the land by his widow after the decree of the suit for declaration of title and possession in favour of the adopted son. After the passing of the decree, the possession of the widow could only be that of a trespasser and it was not open to her to create any right in the land

issues.text: What is the meaning of 'asami shikmi' in the definition of tenant under s.2(v) of the Hyderabad Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1950?

anchor.surface_text: The meaning of the word asami shikmi in the definition of the tenant in s. 2 v does not appear from any provision of the Act but our attention was drawn to the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act, s. 2 13 , according to which asami shikmi means a lessee, whether holding under an instrument or under an oral agreement, and includes a mortgagee of an asami shikmis rights with possession, but does not include a lessee holding directly under Government.

issues.text: Whether the widow could create tenancy rights when restrained by injunction from dealing with the lands?

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had considered at some length the question whether she could create any tenancy rights when there was an injunction restraining her from alienating any property. We do not think it was necessary to go into that question for normally the order of injunction which was passed as an interlocutory measure would not survive the decree of the trial court.

issues.text: Whether the protection under s.5 of the Hyderabad Act is similar to that for tenants inducted by mortgagees under the Bombay Tenancy Act as in Dahya Lal v. Rasul Mohammed?

anchor.surface_text: Learned counsel for the appellants cited the judgment of this Court in Dahya Lal v. Rasul Mohammed Abdul Hakim and it was argued that the object of the Hyderabad Act of 1950 was to afford similar protection as was given to the tenants inducted by mortgagees under the Bombay Tenancy and Agricultural Lands Act, 1948. ... Such is not the position in the case before us.

holdings.text: The appellants before this Court never were the tenants of Ramalingayya. They were induced on the land by his widow after the decree of the suit for declaration of title and possession in favour of the adopted son. After the passing of the decree, the possession of the widow could only be that of a trespasser and it was not open to her to create any right in the land in favour of anybody.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before this Court never were the tenants of Ramalingayya. They were induced on the land by his widow after the decree of the suit for declaration of title and possession in favour of the adopted son. After the passing of the decree, the possession of

holdings.reasoning_summary: Post-decree, widow held as trespasser without title; trespassers cannot confer tenancy rights on others.

holdings.text: Appellants not entitled to benefit of s.5 as their cultivation was not 'lawfully cultivating' the land.

anchor.surface_text: It was argued however both before the High Court and before this Court that the appellants were entitled to the benefit of s. 5, as they were lawfully cultivating the land and should therefore be deemed to be tenants of such land. It was contended that the word

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interpreting 'lawfully' to protect tillers regardless of inducer's title would encourage trespass and create rights from no title; contrary to law.

holdings.text: Widow as trespasser post-decree could not create any right making appellants' cultivation lawful under s.5.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants before this Court never were the tenants of Ramalingayya. They were induced on the land by his widow after the decree of the suit for declaration of title and possession in favour of the adopted son. After the passing of the decree, the possession

holdings.reasoning_summary: Trespassory possession post-decree precludes creation of valid tenancy rights under the Act.

holdings.text: Asami shikmi in s.2(v) means a lessee holding under an instrument or oral agreement.

anchor.surface_text: The meaning of the word asami shikmi in the definition of the tenant in s. 2 v does not appear from any provision of the Act but our attention was drawn to the Hyderabad Land Revenue Act, s. 2 13 , according to which asami shikmi means a lessee, whether

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cross-reference to Land Revenue Act s.2(13); requires valid leasehold, absent here due to trespasser.

holdings.text: It was not necessary to decide whether widow could create tenancy rights despite injunction as interlocutory order does not survive decree.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had considered at some length the question whether she could create any tenancy rights when there was an injunction restraining her from alienating any property. We do not think it was necessary to go into that question for normally the order

holdings.reasoning_summary: Issue unnecessary to decision; injunction temporary.

holdings.text: Protection under Hyderabad s.5 not similar to Bombay Tenancy Act for mortgagee-induced tenants; Dahya Lal inapplicable.

anchor.surface_text: Such is not the position in the case before us. Kaveramma did not induct the tenants on the land in the normal course of management of the property. She put them in possession when she had lost her right to be there and consequently the decision of this

holdings.reasoning_summary: Mortgagee manages with authority derived from owner; trespasser lacks any right to induct.

holdings.text: Bengal Tenancy Act cases (Mohima Chunder, Binad Lal) inapplicable due to entirely different statutory scheme.

anchor.surface_text: It will therefore be noticed that the scheme of the Bengal Tenancy Act was entirely different from the provisions of the Act we have to construe. There occupancy ryots were protected altogether from ejectment but so long as they were non-occupancy ryots

holdings.reasoning_summary: Bengal protects ryots (including non-occupancy) on different grounds; requires lawful induction here.

precedents.citation: Dahya Lal v. Rasul Mohammed Abdul Hakim 1

anchor.surface_text: Dahya Lal v. Rasul Mohammed Abdul Hakim 1  and it was argued that the object of the Hyderabad Act of 1950 was to afford similar protection as was given to the tenants inducted by mortgagees under the Bombay Tenancy and Agricul- tural Land Act, 1948.

precedents.case_name: Dahya Lal v. Rasul Mohammed Abdul Hakim
precedents.cited_proposition: A person lawfully cultivating any land belonging to another person shall be deemed to be a tenant if such land is not cultivated personally by the owner and such person is not a member of the owner's family, servant, or mortgagee in possession; tenants inducted by a mortgagee in possession are deemed tenants of the mortgagor upon redemption.
precedents.cited_holding: A mortgagee in possession is excluded from the class of deemed tenants... the Legislature by restricting the exclusion to mortgagees in possession from the class of deemed tenants intended that the tenant lawfully inducted by the mortgagee shall on redemption of the mortgage be deemed to be tenant of the mortgagor.

precedents.citation: Mohima Chunder Saha v. Hazari Parmanik 1

anchor.surface_text: Mohima Chunder Saha v. Hazari Parmanik 1  the plaintiff, appellant before the High Court sued to eject the defendants and recover possession of the land pertaining to the estate of Char Bantai, of which they stated that they and their predecessors had been for many years in possession as proprietors.

precedents.case_name: Mohima Chunder Saha v. Hazari Parmanik
precedents.cited_proposition: Under the Bengal Tenancy Act, non-occupancy ryots cultivating land placed on the property by persons in possession are protected from ejectment as trespassers and treated as ryots liable only to pay rent, not ejectable at will.
precedents.cited_holding: the defendants were cultivating ryots who were placed on the property by the Collector... they were within the class termed in the Bengal Tenancy Act as non-occupancy ryots... this is in accordance with the general spirit of the Bengal Tenancy Act, which regards a landlord as a rent-receiver...

precedents.citation: Binad Lal Pakrashi v. Kalu Pramanik 1

anchor.surface_text: Binad Lal Pakrashi v. Kalu Pramanik 1 . In this case the plaintiffs who were proprietors sought to oust the defendants from certain lands which they were cultivating in Barakahali village. Previously thereto, there was a dispute regarding these lands between the plaintiffs and the trustees of the late D. N. Tagore

precedents.case_name: Binad Lal Pakrashi v. Kalu Pramanik
precedents.cited_proposition: Under the Bengal Tenancy Act, cultivators settled on land by persons in actual possession of the zemindari acquire rights as ryots against all except true owners with paramount title, and true owners can only claim rent, not khas possession unless under Act provisions.
precedents.cited_holding: The possession of the land... was acquired... by the defendants from the persons who at that time were in actual possession of the zemindari... the plaintiffs could not treat the cultivators as trespassers and obtain khas possession... the defendants are ryots, and the only right... is to the rent payable...
